principles.title: 12 Project Management Principles
principles.content:
The 12 Principles of Project Management

These principles are the foundation of all project work. They guide your decisions, actions, and approach throughout every project. Understanding these principles is critical for the PMP exam.

1. Stewardship

Definition: Acting responsibly with integrity, care, trustworthiness, and compliance in all project activities and decisions.

Key Points:

  • Be accountable for your actions and decisions
  • Make ethical choices even when difficult
  • Consider long-term impacts on stakeholders and the environment
  • Protect stakeholder interests
  • Demonstrate integrity, care, and trustworthiness

2. Team

Definition: Create a collaborative project team environment that promotes ownership, development, and high performance.

Key Points:

  • Build shared vision and clear roles
  • Establish agreed processes
  • Provide mentorship and growth opportunities
  • Foster transparent communication
  • Empower team members to make decisions

3. Stakeholders

Definition: Proactively engage with stakeholders to understand their needs and ensure their support.

Key Points:

  • Identify all stakeholders early
  • Build and maintain relationships
  • Communicate regularly and effectively
  • Balance competing stakeholder needs
  • Address concerns proactively

4. Value

Definition: Focus on delivering value and benefits to stakeholders throughout the project lifecycle.

Key Points:

  • Understand what stakeholders consider valuable
  • Deliver value incrementally when possible
  • Measure and communicate value realization
  • Prioritize work based on value delivery
  • Focus on outcomes, not just outputs

5. Systems Thinking

Definition: Recognize and evaluate the interdependencies within the project and its environment.

Key Points:

  • Understand how project parts interact
  • Consider internal and external factors
  • Recognize cause-and-effect relationships
  • Think holistically about the project
  • Consider the bigger picture

6. Leadership

Definition: Demonstrate leadership behaviors to guide, motivate, and inspire the team.

Key Points:

  • Lead by example
  • Inspire and motivate others
  • Use appropriate leadership style (servant, transformational, etc.)
  • Build trust and respect
  • Guide the team toward goals

7. Tailoring

Definition: Adapt the approach, governance, and processes to suit the project context.

Key Points:

  • One size does not fit all projects
  • Customize your approach based on project needs
  • Consider organizational culture
  • Balance agile and predictive methods when needed (hybrid)
  • Continuously evaluate and adjust

8. Quality

Definition: Focus on quality in both processes and deliverables to meet stakeholder expectations.

Key Points:

  • Build quality in, don't inspect it in
  • Define quality standards early
  • Quality is everyone's responsibility
  • Continuous improvement (Kaizen)
  • Prevention over inspection

9. Complexity

Definition: Navigate complexity through adaptability, resilience, and continuous learning.

Key Points:

  • Embrace uncertainty and change
  • Use iterative approaches for complex work
  • Build in feedback loops
  • Stay resilient when facing challenges
  • Learn and adapt continuously

10. Risk

Definition: Be proactive about identifying, assessing, and responding to opportunities and threats.

Key Points:

  • Identify risks early and continuously
  • Assess both probability and impact
  • Plan responses for top risks
  • Monitor risks throughout the project
  • Look for opportunities (positive risks)

11. Adaptability and Resiliency

Definition: Build adaptability and resiliency into the project approach to respond to change effectively.

Key Points:

  • Embrace change rather than resist it
  • Build flexibility into plans
  • Learn from setbacks
  • Adjust approach based on feedback
  • Recover quickly from disruptions

12. Change

Definition: Enable stakeholders to transition from current to future state through effective change management.

Key Points:

  • Prepare stakeholders for change
  • Communicate the why behind changes
  • Support adoption of new ways of working
  • Address resistance with empathy
  • Ensure sustainable change

üí° Exam Tips for Principles

Common Exam Patterns:

  • Ethical Dilemmas: Always choose the ethical answer (Stewardship)
  • Team Conflicts: Use inclusive, collaborative solutions (Team)
  • Stakeholder Issues: Proactively engage and communicate (Stakeholders)
  • Value Questions: Focus on outcomes and benefits (Value)
  • Change Scenarios: Embrace change, don't resist it (Change, Adaptability)

Key Remember: These principles work together. Many exam questions test multiple principles at once. The answer that demonstrates ethical behavior, collaboration, value focus, and adaptability is usually correct.
principles.examTip: Principles questions appear throughout the exam. Look for answers that show: ethical behavior (Stewardship), collaboration (Team), stakeholder engagement (Stakeholders), value focus (Value), and adaptability (Change). PMI favors servant leadership and inclusive approaches.

domains.title: 8 Performance Domains
domains.content:
The 8 Project Performance Domains

Performance domains are the interconnected areas of project management. They represent what project teams need to focus on to deliver valuable outcomes.

1. Stakeholders Domain

Focus: Activities related to building and maintaining relationships with stakeholders.

Key Activities:

  • Identify all stakeholders
  • Understand their needs and expectations
  • Engage stakeholders appropriately
  • Monitor and manage stakeholder engagement
  • Build trust and consensus

2. Team Domain

Focus: Activities related to establishing team culture, building high-performing teams.

Key Activities:

  • Define team agreements and ground rules
  • Build a shared understanding
  • Foster collaboration
  • Support team development
  • Address impediments
  • Enable decision-making

3. Development Approach and Life Cycle Domain

Focus: Activities related to selecting the appropriate development approach, cadence, and lifecycle phases.

Key Activities:

  • Choose between Predictive, Agile, or Hybrid
  • Define phases and deliverables
  • Plan releases and iterations
  • Determine appropriate cadence
  • Tailor approach to project context

4. Planning Domain

Focus: Activities related to organizing and coordinating work for value delivery.

Key Activities:

  • Estimate work effort and duration
  • Plan schedule and budget
  • Determine resource needs
  • Define quality measures
  • Plan for risks and changes
  • Create communication plans

5. Project Work Domain

Focus: Activities related to establishing processes, managing physical resources, and learning throughout the project.

Key Activities:

  • Execute the work
  • Manage procurement
  • Monitor and control work
  • Capture and share lessons learned
  • Manage project knowledge

6. Delivery Domain

Focus: Activities related to delivering the scope and quality that satisfy stakeholder requirements.

Key Activities:

  • Deliver value incrementally
  • Focus on customer needs
  • Ensure quality standards are met
  • Obtain acceptance of deliverables
  • Verify scope completion

7. Measurement Domain

Focus: Activities related to assessing project performance and taking appropriate action.

Key Activities:

  • Establish performance metrics (KPIs)
  • Monitor progress against baselines
  • Analyze variances (EVM, SPI, CPI)
  • Report performance to stakeholders
  • Take corrective actions

8. Uncertainty Domain

Focus: Activities related to risk and uncertainty throughout the project.

Key Activities:

  • Identify and assess risks
  • Plan risk responses
  • Monitor and control risks
  • Handle issues as they arise
  • Embrace uncertainty and adapt

üí° Exam Tips for Domains

Key Concepts:

  • Integration: Domains are interconnected - decisions in one affect others
  • Tailoring: Domains are adapted based on project context
  • Value-Driven: All domains focus on delivering value
  • Throughout Project: Domains are active across the entire project, not sequential

Common Questions: The exam will ask about interactions between domains (e.g., how Team domain affects Delivery, how Uncertainty affects Planning).
domains.examTip: Domains are interconnected! Understand how they work together. For example: Team domain affects how you approach Planning domain. Uncertainty domain impacts all other domains. Focus on value delivery across all domains.

ethics.title: Ethics & Professional Responsibility
ethics.content:
PMI Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct

As a PMP, you're held to high ethical standards. The PMI Code of Ethics has 4 core values that guide professional conduct.

1. Responsibility

Definition: Take ownership for decisions and actions, and their consequences.

Key Behaviors:

  • Make decisions based on the best interests of society and the public
  • Accept only assignments you're qualified for
  • Fulfill commitments you make
  • Report unethical behavior
  • Take responsibility for errors

Exam Scenario: If you discover an error you made, immediately report it and work to correct it. Don't hide mistakes.

2. Respect

Definition: Show high regard for ourselves, others, and resources entrusted to us.

Key Behaviors:

  • Treat everyone with dignity
  • Respect cultural differences
  • Listen to others' viewpoints
  • Don't use your position to influence others for personal gain
  • Respect intellectual property rights

Exam Scenario: When there's conflict, facilitate respectful discussion. Never use your authority to intimidate others.

3. Fairness

Definition: Make decisions and act impartially and objectively.

Key Behaviors:

  • Avoid conflicts of interest
  • Disclose any conflicts that do exist
  • Don't discriminate
  • Apply rules consistently
  • Provide equal access to information

Exam Scenario: If you have a conflict of interest (e.g., family member bidding on contract), disclose it immediately and recuse yourself from the decision.

4. Honesty

Definition: Understand the truth and act truthfully in communications and conduct.

Key Behaviors:

  • Tell the truth in all circumstances
  • Provide accurate information
  • Don't deceive or mislead
  • Create an environment where others feel safe being honest
  • Be transparent in decision-making

Exam Scenario: If a sponsor asks you to hide project problems, refuse. Always report true project status.

Common Ethical Dilemmas on the Exam

Scenario 1: Discovered Mistake

Situation: You realize you made an error in the project budget.

Wrong: Hide it and hope no one notices

Right: Immediately inform your sponsor and work to correct it

Scenario 2: Conflict of Interest

Situation: Your brother's company bids on a project contract.

Wrong: Favor your brother's bid

Right: Disclose the relationship and recuse yourself from the decision

Scenario 3: Pressure to Deceive

Situation: Sponsor asks you to report project is on track when it's behind.

Wrong: Comply to keep sponsor happy

Right: Report the true status and explain the issues

Scenario 4: Unqualified Assignment

Situation: Offered a project in an industry you know nothing about.

Wrong: Accept because it pays well

Right: Disclose your lack of experience; accept only if you can get qualified or work with someone who is

Scenario 5: Witness Unethical Behavior

Situation: You see a colleague falsifying project records.

Wrong: Ignore it (not your problem)

Right: Report it through appropriate channels

üí° Exam Tips for Ethics

Golden Rules:

  • When in doubt, choose the most ethical answer
  • Honesty > Job security
  • Disclose conflicts of interest immediately
  • Report unethical behavior (it's your responsibility)
  • Never hide problems or mistakes
  • Refuse gifts that could influence decisions
  • Protect confidential information

Common Wrong Answers:

  • "Ignore it" - Never ignore ethical issues
  • "Wait and see" - Act immediately on ethical concerns
  • "Hide the problem" - Always disclose issues
  • "Protect yourself first" - Do what's right for the project/organization
ethics.examTip: Ethics questions are often easy to spot but can be tricky. Always choose the answer that is most honest, transparent, and ethical - even if it means personal cost. PMI expects PMs to uphold the highest standards. When you see an ethical issue, the answer is almost always to disclose it immediately and report through proper channels.

exam-strategy.title: PMP Exam Format & Strategy
exam-strategy.content:
PMP Exam Format (2026)

Exam Structure

Total Questions: 185 questions (175 scored + 10 pretest)

Duration: 240 minutes (4 hours)

Breaks: Two optional 10-minute breaks (after Q60 and Q120)

Question Types:

  • Multiple Choice (one correct answer) - ~70%
  • Multiple Response (select 2-3 answers) - ~15%
  • Matching (drag and drop) - ~10%
  • Fill in the blank / Hotspot - ~5%

Domain Distribution

DomainPercentageQuestions
People33%~61 questions
Process41%~76 questions
Business Environment26%~48 questions

Methodology Mix

  • Agile/Hybrid: ~60% of questions
  • Predictive (Traditional): ~40% of questions

Test-Taking Strategy

Before You Start

Brain Dump (First 5 minutes):

  1. Write down all formulas on provided notepad/whiteboard
  2. Write the 12 Principles
  3. Write the five project phases (Initiating, Planning, Executing, Monitoring & Controlling, Closing) and performance domains
  4. Write key Agile concepts

What to Write:

  • EVM formulas (EV, PV, AC, CV, SV, CPI, SPI, EAC, ETC, VAC)
  • Communication Channels: n(n-1)/2
  • Critical Path concepts
  • 12 Principles list
  • Agile Manifesto values

Time Management

Pacing:

  • 240 minutes √∑ 185 questions = ~1.3 minutes per question
  • Target pace: 90 seconds per question
  • After 60 questions: Check time (should have ~150 min left)
  • After 120 questions: Check time (should have ~80 min left)

Use Your Breaks:

  • Break 1 (after Q60): Stretch, bathroom, clear your head
  • Break 2 (after Q120): Rest, refocus, you're almost there!

Answering Questions

Step-by-Step Approach:

  1. Read Carefully: Understand what's being asked
  2. Identify Context: Agile or Predictive? What domain?
  3. Eliminate Wrong Answers: Cross out clearly wrong options
  4. Look for Key Words: "BEST", "FIRST", "NEXT", "MOST"
  5. Choose the PMI Way: Servant leadership, collaboration, value focus

Key Words to Watch:

  • "FIRST" - What's the immediate next step?
  • "BEST" - All may be right, but which is MOST right?
  • "NEXT" - What's the proper sequence?
  • "MOST likely" - Think probability

The PMI Mindset

PMI Favors:

  • ‚úÖ Servant leadership over command-and-control
  • ‚úÖ Collaboration over working in silos
  • ‚úÖ Proactive over reactive
  • ‚úÖ Inclusive approaches over exclusive
  • ‚úÖ Ethical behavior over shortcuts
  • ‚úÖ Value delivery over just completing tasks
  • ‚úÖ Embracing change over resisting it
  • ‚úÖ Team empowerment over micromanagement

Red Flag Wrong Answers:

  • ‚ùå "Ignore the problem"
  • ‚ùå "Hide issues from stakeholders"
  • ‚ùå "Make decisions without the team"
  • ‚ùå "Deny the change request"
  • ‚ùå "Escalate immediately" (without trying to solve first)
  • ‚ùå "Consult the PMBOK" (not a real-time reference!)

Situational Questions

Common Scenarios:

  • Conflict between team members: Facilitate collaborative solution
  • Stakeholder unhappy: Meet with them, understand concerns, engage proactively
  • Change request: Evaluate impact, present to CCB, never deny outright
  • Team member underperforming: One-on-one discussion, identify root cause, provide training
  • Risk identified: Assess, plan response, communicate
  • Project behind schedule: Analyze cause, present options, don't hide it

Domain-Specific Tips

People Domain (33%)

  • Focus on servant leadership
  • Always choose collaborative solutions
  • Empower the team to make decisions
  • Address conflicts through facilitation
  • Training is almost always the right answer

Process Domain (41%)

  • Know your formulas (EVM especially)
  • Understand change control process
  • Know the difference between issues and risks
  • Quality is planned in, not inspected in
  • Integrated change control = evaluate, approve, implement

Business Environment Domain (26%)

  • NEW in 2026: Much higher weight!
  • Focus on value delivery and benefits realization
  • Understand compliance is mandatory
  • Organizational change management is key
  • External factors require adaptation

Agile Questions (60%)

  • Scrum: Know roles, ceremonies, artifacts
  • Values: Individuals > processes, Working software > documentation, Customer collaboration > contracts, Responding to change > following plan
  • Key Concepts: Iterations, sprints, retrospectives, daily standups, product backlog, user stories
  • Remember: Servant leadership is crucial in Agile

Final Tips

The Week Before:

  • Review formulas daily
  • Take practice exams
  • Review the 12 Principles
  • Rest well the night before

Exam Day:

  • Arrive early (15-20 minutes)
  • Bring valid ID
  • No food, drink, phone, watch allowed
  • You'll get a notepad/whiteboard
  • Stay calm, you've prepared for this!

During the Exam:

  • Do your brain dump first
  • Read questions carefully
  • Watch your pace
  • Use your breaks
  • Flag difficult questions and move on
  • Review flagged questions if time permits
  • Trust your preparation!

üí° Remember

You've studied hard. You know the material. Trust your instincts. When in doubt, choose the answer that:

  • ‚úÖ Is most ethical
  • ‚úÖ Is most collaborative
  • ‚úÖ Focuses on value
  • ‚úÖ Involves the team
  • ‚úÖ Is proactive, not reactive

You've got this! üéØ
exam-strategy.examTip: The exam tests your ability to apply PM knowledge, not just memorize. Always think: What would a servant leader do? What's most ethical? What delivers value? What involves the team? The PMI mindset is key - choose answers that demonstrate collaboration, transparency, value focus, and adaptability.

d1t1.title: Domain 1 Task 1: Manage conflict
d1t1.content:
Domain 1 Task 1: Manage conflict

Introduction

Domain 1 Task 1: Manage conflict is a critical task within the People domain, which represents 42% of the PMP exam. This task focuses on the essential skills required to manage conflict effectively throughout the project lifecycle.

As Andrew Ramdayal emphasizes in his PMP training, "In this video, I'm gonna be talking about Domain 1: Task 1, manage conflict." Understanding how to manage conflict is not just about passing the exam‚Äîit's about becoming an effective project manager who can navigate real-world challenges with confidence.

This task will appear in multiple exam questions, often disguised in situational scenarios. You'll need to demonstrate your understanding of PMI's preferred approach: collaborative, inclusive, and value-focused decision-making.

Key Concepts and Learning Points

Based on the Andrew Ramdayal TIA Education transcript, here are the essential concepts you must understand:

Core Principles:

  • First thing I'm gonna do, any problems? Why? Because I know there's gonna be some kind of conflict.
  • And as a project manager, you have to be ready to manage these conflicts.
  • Now, let's take a look at what PMI wants us to know.
  • So the first thing up, manage conflicts.
  • What the first thing you're gonna be able to do is you wanna interpret that particular source and stage of the conflict.
  • You wanna say to yourself, where did this conflict come from? What started the conflict? And then you wanna know the stage of the conflict, like how much has it escalated? One of the main things with being a good project manager is you don't want conflicts to escalate too high up.
  • On any exam question, where you have to solve a conflict between any type of team, any type of team or stakeholders, whatever combination you want.
  • Remember, I can't emphasize this enough, any choice that you see, ask yourself this question, is this the inclusive choice? Is this the choice that includes everyone joining in and helping out to come up with a solution? Is this the choice that includes them participating? That's gonna be the answer.

Detailed Understanding:

about Domain 1: Task 1, manage conflict. You know, I personally believe that project management shouldn't be called project management....

Why This Matters:

In real-world project management, you will constantly need to manage conflict. The PMI approach emphasizes servant leadership, collaboration, and stakeholder engagement. On the exam, you must recognize situations where this task applies and choose the answer that demonstrates these values.

Important Terms for This Task: agile, conflict

How to Apply This on the PMP Exam

When you encounter exam questions related to manage conflict, use this framework:

Step 1: Identify the Question Type

Look for keywords:

  • "What should you do FIRST?" - Focus on immediate, proactive actions
  • "What is the BEST approach?" - Look for the most collaborative, inclusive option
  • "What should you do NEXT?" - Follow the logical sequence of PMI processes
  • "How should you handle this?" - Choose servant leadership approaches

Step 2: Apply the PMI Mindset

PMI expects project managers to:

  • Be proactive, not reactive - Address issues before they escalate
  • Be collaborative, not autocratic - Involve the team in solutions
  • Be transparent, not secretive - Communicate openly with stakeholders
  • Be ethical, always - Choose integrity over shortcuts
  • Focus on value - Ensure actions align with business objectives

Step 3: Eliminate Wrong Answers

Immediately eliminate options that suggest:

  • ‚ùå Ignoring or hiding problems
  • ‚ùå Making decisions without consulting the team
  • ‚ùå Escalating before attempting to resolve
  • ‚ùå Blaming or punishing team members
  • ‚ùå "Consulting the PMBOK Guide" (not practical in real-time)

Step 4: Choose the PMI Way

The correct answer will typically involve:

  • ‚úÖ Facilitating collaborative discussions
  • ‚úÖ Engaging stakeholders proactively
  • ‚úÖ Following established processes (change control, risk management)
  • ‚úÖ Providing training or coaching when skills are lacking
  • ‚úÖ Focusing on root causes, not symptoms

Common Exam Scenarios for This Task

Here are typical question patterns you'll encounter on the exam:

üìå Scenario 1: Team Member Conflict

Two team members are arguing about which technical approach to use for a critical deliverable. The conflict is affecting team morale. What should you do FIRST?

  • ‚ùå Option A: Make the technical decision yourself based on your expertise
  • ‚ùå Option B: Speak to each team member separately and choose the better solution
  • ‚ùå Option C: Escalate to the sponsor for a decision
  • ‚úÖ Option D (CORRECT): Facilitate a meeting with both team members to collaboratively evaluate options and reach consensus

Why D is correct: This demonstrates inclusive problem-solving, servant leadership, and empowering the team to resolve issues collaboratively.

üìå Scenario 2: Skills and Training Gap

A team member is struggling with a new tool required for the project and is falling behind on deliverables. What should you do?

  • ‚ùå Option A: Reassign their work to a more experienced team member
  • ‚ùå Option B: Remove them from the project
  • ‚ùå Option C: Extend the deadline to give them more time
  • ‚úÖ Option D (CORRECT): Arrange training for the team member and provide coaching/mentoring support

Why D is correct: PMI favors developing team capabilities through training and support rather than punitive or avoidance approaches.

üìå Scenario 3: Stakeholder Disagreement

A key stakeholder is unhappy with the project direction and is threatening to withdraw support. What is the BEST course of action?

  • ‚ùå Option A: Continue with the current plan as approved
  • ‚ùå Option B: Immediately change the project to meet their demands
  • ‚ùå Option C: Report the stakeholder to the sponsor
  • ‚úÖ Option D (CORRECT): Schedule a meeting to understand their concerns, review project objectives, and find mutually acceptable solutions

Why D is correct: Demonstrates proactive stakeholder engagement, collaborative problem-solving, and focus on maintaining relationships while delivering value.

The PMI Mindset for This Task

To consistently choose correct answers, you must think like PMI. Here's the PMI perspective on manage conflict:

‚úì PMI Values (Choose these approaches):

  • Servant Leadership: Remove obstacles, support the team, empower decision-making
  • Collaboration Over Control: Facilitate discussions rather than dictating solutions
  • Inclusion Not Exclusion: Involve all relevant parties in problem-solving
  • Proactive Communication: Address issues early before they escalate
  • Continuous Learning: Support training, coaching, and skill development
  • Value-Driven: Ensure actions deliver business value
  • Ethical Behavior: Always choose integrity and transparency
  • Process Adherence: Follow established governance (change control, risk management)

‚úó Anti-Patterns (Avoid these approaches):

  • Command and Control: Making all decisions unilaterally
  • Avoidance: Ignoring problems or hoping they resolve themselves
  • Blame Culture: Punishing team members for mistakes
  • Premature Escalation: Going to leadership before attempting to resolve
  • Secrecy: Hiding problems from stakeholders
  • Shortcuts: Bypassing processes or governance
  • Exclusion: Making decisions without team or stakeholder input

Direct Exam Guidance from the Transcript:

"I am a hundred percent sure you're gonna have quite a few questions on your exam about managing conflicts between team members, between a customer and a team member, between you and a team member, between you and a sponsor, you and a functional manager, a functional manager and a team member"

üí° Exam Tips and Success Strategies

üéØ Quick Decision Framework:

When stuck between two answers, ask yourself:

  1. Is this collaborative? (PMI prefers inclusive approaches)
  2. Is this proactive? (PMI prefers preventing over fixing)
  3. Does this empower the team? (PMI prefers servant leadership)
  4. Is this ethical and transparent? (PMI always chooses integrity)
  5. Does this follow the process? (PMI prefers governance adherence)

If an answer scores 4-5 "yes" answers, it's likely correct!

üéØ Common Trap Answers:

PMI loves to include these wrong answers to test if you truly understand the PMI way:

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Review the PMBOK Guide" - Too theoretical for real-time situations
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Escalate to the sponsor" - Escalate only after trying to resolve yourself
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Wait and see if it resolves" - Be proactive, not reactive
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Make the decision yourself" - Include the team when appropriate
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Ignore it and continue" - Never ignore issues
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Remove the problematic person" - Support and develop, don't eliminate

üéØ Context Clues to Watch For:

  • Agile vs Predictive: The approach may differ based on methodology
  • Regulatory Environment: Compliance may require more directive approaches
  • Team Maturity: Experienced teams get more autonomy; new teams need more guidance
  • Risk Level: High-risk situations may require more oversight

üéØ People Domain Specific Tip:

This task is part of the People domain, which is all about relationships, leadership, and team dynamics. People domain questions test your emotional intelligence and ability to work with diverse stakeholders. Key themes: servant leadership, collaboration, empowerment, training, communication, conflict resolution. The answer almost always involves directly engaging with people rather than avoiding or delegating the interaction.

üéØ Final Reminders:

  • This task connects to the 12 Principles (especially Team, Stakeholders, Leadership)
  • This task relates to the 8 Performance Domains (especially People)
  • Agile Relevance: low - More common in Predictive projects
  • Remember: agile, conflict

You've got this! Keep practicing and trust the PMI mindset. üéØ
d1t1.examTip: Domain 1 Task 1: Manage conflict is part of the People domain (42% of exam). More relevant to Predictive/Traditional projects - expect waterfall, sequential planning questions. Key concepts: agile, conflict.

d1t2.title: Domain 1 Task 2: Lead a team
d1t2.content:
Domain 1 Task 2: Lead a team

Introduction

Domain 1 Task 2: Lead a team is a critical task within the People domain, which represents 42% of the PMP exam. This task focuses on the essential skills required to lead a team effectively throughout the project lifecycle.

As Andrew Ramdayal emphasizes in his PMP training, "In this video, I'm gonna be going over domain one: People, task two: Lead a Team." Understanding how to lead a team is not just about passing the exam‚Äîit's about becoming an effective project manager who can navigate real-world challenges with confidence.

This task will appear in multiple exam questions, often disguised in situational scenarios. You'll need to demonstrate your understanding of PMI's preferred approach: collaborative, inclusive, and value-focused decision-making.

Key Concepts and Learning Points

Based on the Andrew Ramdayal TIA Education transcript, here are the essential concepts you must understand:

Core Principles:

  • So there are some really important things we need to know as being a project manager in order to have a successful project.
  • And the first thing up when leading a team is you want to set a clear vision and a mission.
  • The next thing you wanna do, support diversity and inclusion.
  • You're gonna have to remember that in today's world you're gonna have a lot of different people with different backgrounds, different cultures, even in fact, different languages, especially on virtual teams, different behavior types, thought process.
  • A directive leader? Are we gonna be a collaborative leader? You have to know when to use one over the other.
  • Always remember what I told you in Agile, let the team fix it.
  • But remember, on certain projects with directive where regulations are involved, you might just not do that.

Detailed Understanding:

It is part of any project manager's job to lead the team. The team will look at you for the vision. They would look at you to help solve conflicts....

Why This Matters:

In real-world project management, you will constantly need to lead a team. The PMI approach emphasizes servant leadership, collaboration, and stakeholder engagement. On the exam, you must recognize situations where this task applies and choose the answer that demonstrates these values.

Important Terms for This Task: collaboration, servant leadership, agile, virtual team, regulatory

How to Apply This on the PMP Exam

When you encounter exam questions related to lead a team, use this framework:

Step 1: Identify the Question Type

Look for keywords:

  • "What should you do FIRST?" - Focus on immediate, proactive actions
  • "What is the BEST approach?" - Look for the most collaborative, inclusive option
  • "What should you do NEXT?" - Follow the logical sequence of PMI processes
  • "How should you handle this?" - Choose servant leadership approaches

Step 2: Apply the PMI Mindset

PMI expects project managers to:

  • Be proactive, not reactive - Address issues before they escalate
  • Be collaborative, not autocratic - Involve the team in solutions
  • Be transparent, not secretive - Communicate openly with stakeholders
  • Be ethical, always - Choose integrity over shortcuts
  • Focus on value - Ensure actions align with business objectives

Step 3: Eliminate Wrong Answers

Immediately eliminate options that suggest:

  • ‚ùå Ignoring or hiding problems
  • ‚ùå Making decisions without consulting the team
  • ‚ùå Escalating before attempting to resolve

d3t4.title: Domain 3 Task 4: Support organizational change
d3t4.content:
Domain 3 Task 4: Support organizational change

Introduction

Domain 3 Task 4: Support organizational change is a critical task within the Business Environment domain, which represents 8% of the PMP exam. This task focuses on the essential skills required to support organizational change effectively throughout the project lifecycle.

As Andrew Ramdayal emphasizes in his PMP training, "In this video, I'm gonna be going over Domain 3: Task 4, Support Organizational Change." Understanding how to support organizational change is not just about passing the exam‚Äîit's about becoming an effective project manager who can navigate real-world challenges with confidence.

This task will appear in multiple exam questions, often disguised in situational scenarios. You'll need to demonstrate your understanding of PMI's preferred approach: collaborative, inclusive, and value-focused decision-making.

Key Concepts and Learning Points

Based on the Andrew Ramdayal TIA Education transcript, here are the essential concepts you must understand:

Core Principles:

  • But anyhow, what does it take? What is the single most important factor that the organization needs to have to sustain, to pass I should say, the test of time? That is to build a culture of organizational change.
  • Are they willing to change or are they not? If you guy remember Blackberry.
  • Nothing wrong with that, but you have to be prepared to deal with these changes.

Detailed Understanding:

Domain 3: Task 4, Support Organizational Change. Before I get started on this, lemme just say this. I believe that there is one thing...

Why This Matters:

In real-world project management, you will constantly need to support organizational change. The PMI approach emphasizes servant leadership, collaboration, and stakeholder engagement. On the exam, you must recognize situations where this task applies and choose the answer that demonstrates these values.

Important Terms for This Task: scope, organizational, change

How to Apply This on the PMP Exam

When you encounter exam questions related to support organizational change, use this framework:

Step 1: Identify the Question Type

Look for keywords:

  • "What should you do FIRST?" - Focus on immediate, proactive actions
  • "What is the BEST approach?" - Look for the most collaborative, inclusive option
  • "What should you do NEXT?" - Follow the logical sequence of PMI processes
  • "How should you handle this?" - Choose servant leadership approaches

Step 2: Apply the PMI Mindset

PMI expects project managers to:

  • Be proactive, not reactive - Address issues before they escalate
  • Be collaborative, not autocratic - Involve the team in solutions
  • Be transparent, not secretive - Communicate openly with stakeholders
  • Be ethical, always - Choose integrity over shortcuts
  • Focus on value - Ensure actions align with business objectives

Step 3: Eliminate Wrong Answers

Immediately eliminate options that suggest:

  • ‚ùå Ignoring or hiding problems
  • ‚ùå Making decisions without consulting the team
  • ‚ùå Escalating before attempting to resolve
  • ‚ùå Blaming or punishing team members
  • ‚ùå "Consulting the PMBOK Guide" (not practical in real-time)

Step 4: Choose the PMI Way

The correct answer will typically involve:

  • ‚úÖ Facilitating collaborative discussions
  • ‚úÖ Engaging stakeholders proactively
  • ‚úÖ Following established processes (change control, risk management)
  • ‚úÖ Providing training or coaching when skills are lacking
  • ‚úÖ Focusing on root causes, not symptoms

Common Exam Scenarios for This Task

Here are typical question patterns you'll encounter on the exam:

üìå Scenario 1: Team Member Conflict

Two team members are arguing about which technical approach to use for a critical deliverable. The conflict is affecting team morale. What should you do FIRST?

  • ‚ùå Option A: Make the technical decision yourself based on your expertise
  • ‚ùå Option B: Speak to each team member separately and choose the better solution
  • ‚ùå Option C: Escalate to the sponsor for a decision
  • ‚úÖ Option D (CORRECT): Facilitate a meeting with both team members to collaboratively evaluate options and reach consensus

Why D is correct: This demonstrates inclusive problem-solving, servant leadership, and empowering the team to resolve issues collaboratively.

üìå Scenario 2: Skills and Training Gap

A team member is struggling with a new tool required for the project and is falling behind on deliverables. What should you do?

  • ‚ùå Option A: Reassign their work to a more experienced team member
  • ‚ùå Option B: Remove them from the project
  • ‚ùå Option C: Extend the deadline to give them more time
  • ‚úÖ Option D (CORRECT): Arrange training for the team member and provide coaching/mentoring support

Why D is correct: PMI favors developing team capabilities through training and support rather than punitive or avoidance approaches.

üìå Scenario 3: Stakeholder Disagreement

A key stakeholder is unhappy with the project direction and is threatening to withdraw support. What is the BEST course of action?

  • ‚ùå Option A: Continue with the current plan as approved
  • ‚ùå Option B: Immediately change the project to meet their demands
  • ‚ùå Option C: Report the stakeholder to the sponsor
  • ‚úÖ Option D (CORRECT): Schedule a meeting to understand their concerns, review project objectives, and find mutually acceptable solutions

Why D is correct: Demonstrates proactive stakeholder engagement, collaborative problem-solving, and focus on maintaining relationships while delivering value.

The PMI Mindset for This Task

To consistently choose correct answers, you must think like PMI. Here's the PMI perspective on support organizational change:

‚úì PMI Values (Choose these approaches):

  • Servant Leadership: Remove obstacles, support the team, empower decision-making
  • Collaboration Over Control: Facilitate discussions rather than dictating solutions
  • Inclusion Not Exclusion: Involve all relevant parties in problem-solving
  • Proactive Communication: Address issues early before they escalate
  • Continuous Learning: Support training, coaching, and skill development
  • Value-Driven: Ensure actions deliver business value
  • Ethical Behavior: Always choose integrity and transparency
  • Process Adherence: Follow established governance (change control, risk management)

‚úó Anti-Patterns (Avoid these approaches):

  • Command and Control: Making all decisions unilaterally
  • Avoidance: Ignoring problems or hoping they resolve themselves
  • Blame Culture: Punishing team members for mistakes
  • Premature Escalation: Going to leadership before attempting to resolve
  • Secrecy: Hiding problems from stakeholders
  • Shortcuts: Bypassing processes or governance
  • Exclusion: Making decisions without team or stakeholder input

Direct Exam Guidance from the Transcript:

"And this is a very famous drag-and-drop, that you probably should expect to see on your exam"

üí° Exam Tips and Success Strategies

üéØ Quick Decision Framework:

When stuck between two answers, ask yourself:

  1. Is this collaborative? (PMI prefers inclusive approaches)
  2. Is this proactive? (PMI prefers preventing over fixing)
  3. Does this empower the team? (PMI prefers servant leadership)
  4. Is this ethical and transparent? (PMI always chooses integrity)
  5. Does this follow the process? (PMI prefers governance adherence)

If an answer scores 4-5 "yes" answers, it's likely correct!

üéØ Common Trap Answers:

PMI loves to include these wrong answers to test if you truly understand the PMI way:

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Review the PMBOK Guide" - Too theoretical for real-time situations
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Escalate to the sponsor" - Escalate only after trying to resolve yourself
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Wait and see if it resolves" - Be proactive, not reactive
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Make the decision yourself" - Include the team when appropriate
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Ignore it and continue" - Never ignore issues
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è "Remove the problematic person" - Support and develop, don't eliminate

üéØ Context Clues to Watch For:

  • Agile vs Predictive: The approach may differ based on methodology
  • Regulatory Environment: Compliance may require more directive approaches
  • Team Maturity: Experienced teams get more autonomy; new teams need more guidance
  • Risk Level: High-risk situations may require more oversight

üéØ Business Environment Specific Tip:

This task is part of the Business Environment domain, which emphasizes value delivery and organizational alignment. Business Environment questions test your understanding of strategy, compliance, benefits realization, and change management. Key themes: benefits realization, compliance, organizational change, external factors, strategic alignment. The answer focuses on delivering value to the organization.

üéØ Final Reminders:

  • This task connects to the 12 Principles (especially Team, Stakeholders, Leadership)
  • This task relates to the 8 Performance Domains (especially Business Environment)
  • Agile Relevance: low - More common in Predictive projects
  • Remember: scope, organizational, change

You've got this! Keep practicing and trust the PMI mindset. üéØ

agile-manifesto.title: Agile Manifesto & Principles
agile-manifesto.content:
The Agile Manifesto: Foundation of Modern Project Management

Understanding the Agile Manifesto is critical for the PMP exam. Approximately 60% of exam questions involve Agile or Hybrid approaches, making this one of the most heavily tested areas.

Historical Context: The Snowbird Meeting (2001)

In February 2001, seventeen software developers met at the Snowbird ski resort in Utah. They were frustrated with traditional, documentation-heavy development processes that couldn't keep up with rapidly changing business needs. These pioneers included:

  • Kent Beck (Extreme Programming creator)
  • Martin Fowler (thought leader in software design)
  • Jeff Sutherland and Ken Schwaber (Scrum co-creators)
  • And 13 other influential developers

Over three days, they crafted what would become the Agile Manifesto‚Äîa revolutionary statement that changed how organizations approach project delivery.

Why This Matters for the Exam: PMI has embraced Agile principles across all project types. The exam tests whether you understand when and how to apply these values, not just whether you've memorized them.

The 4 Core Values of Agile

Critical Exam Point: The Manifesto states we value items on the left MORE than items on the right‚Äînot instead of. Both sides have value, but Agile prioritizes the left side.

Value 1: Individuals and Interactions Over Processes and Tools

What It Means: People and their collaboration are more important than the processes they follow or the tools they use.

Key Principles:

  • Face-to-face conversation is the most effective communication method
  • Self-organizing teams make better decisions than rigid hierarchies
  • Trust and collaboration beat strict procedures
  • Adapt processes to fit the team, not the team to fit processes

Exam Scenarios:

  • Question: "Team wants to use a different collaboration tool than the one mandated by the PMO. What should you do?"
  • PMI Answer: Support the team's choice if it improves their collaboration (individuals > tools)
  • Wrong Answer: Enforce the PMO standard regardless of team preference

Real-World Application: If your team collaborates effectively using whiteboards and sticky notes instead of expensive software, that's perfectly valid. The conversation matters more than the medium.

Value 2: Working Software Over Comprehensive Documentation

What It Means: Delivering functional products that provide value is more important than creating detailed documentation about those products.

Key Principles:

  • Create just enough documentation to support the work
  • Working deliverables are the primary measure of progress
  • Documentation should serve the team, not the other way around
  • Demonstrate value through tangible results

For Non-Software Projects: Replace "working software" with "working deliverables" or "usable increments." This value applies to construction, marketing, research‚Äîany project type.

Exam Scenarios:

  • Question: "Stakeholder requests detailed technical specifications before any development begins. The team wants to build a prototype first. What do you do?"
  • PMI Answer: Build a prototype to demonstrate functionality, then document based on what you learn (working product > documentation)
  • Wrong Answer: Complete all documentation before starting any development work

Exam Trap: This does NOT mean "no documentation." Regulatory, compliance, and safety-critical projects require documentation. The point is to avoid documentation for documentation's sake.

Value 3: Customer Collaboration Over Contract Negotiation

What It Means: Ongoing partnership with customers produces better outcomes than rigid adherence to initial contract terms.

Key Principles:

  • Involve customers throughout the project, not just at the beginning and end
  • Contracts should enable collaboration, not prevent it
  • Welcome customer feedback and changing requirements
  • Build partnerships, not adversarial relationships

Exam Scenarios:

  • Question: "Customer wants to add new features discovered during development. Your contract specifies fixed scope. What do you do?"
  • PMI Answer: Collaborate with the customer to assess the value, discuss trade-offs, and adjust the plan together (collaboration > rigid contracts)
  • Wrong Answer: Refuse the change because it's not in the original contract

Contracts in Agile: Agile-friendly contracts include time-and-materials agreements, graduated fixed-price contracts, or contracts with change-friendly clauses. The exam favors collaborative contract approaches.

Value 4: Responding to Change Over Following a Plan

What It Means: Adapting to new information and changing circumstances delivers more value than rigidly following an outdated plan.

Key Principles:

  • Plans are valuable, but they should evolve as you learn
  • Change is a source of competitive advantage, not a problem
  • Regular inspection and adaptation keep plans relevant
  • Business needs change‚Äîprojects should too

Exam Scenarios:

  • Question: "Market conditions have changed since project planning. The original deliverable is now less valuable, but a modified version would be highly valuable. What do you do?"
  • PMI Answer: Collaborate with stakeholders to re-prioritize and adapt the plan to deliver maximum value (responding to change > following plan)
  • Wrong Answer: Continue with the original plan because it was approved by stakeholders

Common Misconception: "Responding to change" doesn't mean chaos or no planning. Agile projects have plans‚Äîthey're just adaptive rather than fixed.

The 12 Principles Behind the Agile Manifesto

These principles provide actionable guidance for applying the four values. Know these for the exam‚Äîthey appear in scenario questions testing your understanding of Agile thinking.

Principle 1: Our highest priority is to satisfy the customer through early and continuous delivery of valuable software.

Exam Focus: Value delivery is continuous, not just at project end.

  • Deliver working increments frequently (weeks, not months)
  • Each increment should provide customer value
  • Early delivery allows for early feedback

Key Takeaway: Don't wait until the end to deliver value. Release frequently.

Principle 2: Welcome changing requirements, even late in development. Agile processes harness change for the customer's competitive advantage.

Exam Focus: Change is an opportunity, not a threat.

  • Never deny or resist change requests outright
  • Evaluate changes based on value they provide
  • Use change to improve project outcomes

Exam Trap: PMI expects you to embrace change, but still evaluate impact and make informed decisions. "Welcome change" doesn't mean "accept everything blindly."

Principle 3: Deliver working software frequently, from a couple of weeks to a couple of months, with a preference to the shorter timescale.

Exam Focus: Short iterations enable faster feedback.

  • Typical sprint length: 1-4 weeks (2 weeks is common)
  • Shorter cycles reduce risk and improve adaptability
  • Each iteration produces potentially releasable increment

Principle 4: Business people and developers must work together daily throughout the project.

Exam Focus: Collaboration is continuous, not periodic.

  • Product Owner is readily available to the team
  • Daily interaction prevents misunderstandings
  • Business context informs technical decisions

Application: This is why the Product Owner in Scrum is a critical role‚Äîthey provide constant business guidance.

Principle 5: Build projects around motivated individuals. Give them the environment and support they need, and trust them to get the job done.

Exam Focus: Trust and empowerment drive performance.

  • This reflects the Servant Leadership principle
  • Remove obstacles rather than micromanage
  • Provide autonomy within clear boundaries

Exam Scenario: When team asks to make implementation decisions, the answer is usually "empower them to decide" (unless it affects architecture or external interfaces).

Principle 6: The most efficient and effective method of conveying information to and within a development team is face-to-face conversation.

Exam Focus: Rich communication beats written documentation.

  • Video calls with cameras on are the virtual equivalent
  • Daily standups leverage this principle
  • Prefer conversations over emails when possible

Exam Tip: In virtual team questions, choose video conferencing over email or phone when discussing complex topics.

Principle 7: Working software is the primary measure of progress.

Exam Focus: Measure progress by deliverables, not activity.

  • Don't measure progress by tasks completed or hours worked
  • Demonstrate actual working functionality
  • Activities matter less than outcomes

Application: This is why Agile teams demo working features in Sprint Reviews, not PowerPoint slides about what they're doing.

Principle 8: Agile processes promote sustainable development. The sponsors, developers, and users should be able to maintain a constant pace indefinitely.

Exam Focus: Avoid burnout; pace is important.

  • No "death marches" or constant overtime
  • Sustainable pace produces better quality
  • Velocity should stabilize over time

Exam Scenario: If team velocity is declining or team is working excessive overtime, address the root cause rather than push harder.

Principle 9: Continuous attention to technical excellence and good design enhances agility.

Exam Focus: Quality enables speed.

  • Poor quality creates technical debt that slows future work
  • Build quality in from the start
  • Refactoring and improvement are ongoing activities

Connection to PMI Principles: This aligns with the Quality principle‚Äîquality is everyone's responsibility.

Principle 10: Simplicity‚Äîthe art of maximizing the amount of work not done‚Äîis essential.

Exam Focus: Do the minimum necessary to deliver value.

  • Avoid gold-plating and unnecessary features
  • Focus on high-value work only
  • YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It) mindset

Exam Application: When prioritizing features, choose the minimal set that delivers maximum value.

Principle 11: The best architectures, requirements, and designs emerge from self-organizing teams.

Exam Focus: Teams should determine "how" to do the work.

  • Cross-functional teams make better technical decisions
  • Self-organization doesn't mean no structure‚Äîit means autonomy within guardrails
  • Teams own their processes and practices

Exam Scenario: Product Owner sets the "what" (features/priorities), team determines the "how" (technical implementation).

Principle 12: At regular intervals, the team reflects on how to become more effective, then tunes and adjusts its behavior accordingly.

Exam Focus: Continuous improvement through retrospectives.

  • Retrospectives should occur every iteration
  • Team identifies improvements and implements them
  • Inspect and adapt applies to the team's process, not just the product

Application: Sprint Retrospectives in Scrum directly implement this principle.

How the Agile Manifesto Guides PMI's Approach

PMI has evolved significantly since the days of purely predictive (waterfall) project management. The current PMP exam reflects PMI's recognition that:

  • No single approach fits all projects - Some projects need predictive planning, some need Agile, many need hybrid
  • Value delivery is paramount - The project management principles emphasize delivering value over just completing tasks
  • Adaptability is essential - The Adaptability and Resiliency principle reflects Agile thinking
  • People matter most - Servant leadership and team empowerment align with Agile values

PMI's Integration of Agile:

  • The Value Principle (#4) comes directly from Agile thinking
  • The Adaptability Principle (#11) embraces "responding to change"
  • The Team Principle (#2) reflects "individuals and interactions"
  • The Delivery Domain emphasizes incremental delivery

Common Exam Scenarios Testing Manifesto Understanding

Scenario 1: Documentation vs. Working Product

Situation: Your sponsor asks for a comprehensive requirements document before starting development. The team wants to build a minimal viable product (MVP) and iterate.

Analysis: This tests Value 2 (working software over documentation).

Wrong Answer: Create the full requirements document as requested

Right Answer: Collaborate with the sponsor to understand their concerns, then propose building an MVP to validate requirements through working functionality

Scenario 2: Contract vs. Collaboration

Situation: A customer wants to modify the scope mid-project. Your contract has a formal change control process that takes weeks to execute.

Analysis: This tests Value 3 (customer collaboration over contract negotiation).

Wrong Answer: Deny the change or insist on lengthy formal process

Right Answer: Meet with the customer to understand the business value, assess impact collaboratively, and find a way to accommodate valuable changes quickly

Scenario 3: Plan vs. Adaptation

Situation: Market research reveals that a planned feature is no longer needed, but a different feature would be highly valuable. Your project plan is approved and baselined.

Analysis: This tests Value 4 (responding to change over following a plan).

Wrong Answer: Stick to the plan because it's been approved

Right Answer: Present the new information to stakeholders and recommend re-prioritizing to deliver maximum value

Scenario 4: Tools vs. People

Situation: Your team is collaborating effectively using simple tools (whiteboard, sticky notes). The PMO mandates use of an expensive project management software.

Analysis: This tests Value 1 (individuals and interactions over processes and tools).

Wrong Answer: Immediately enforce the PMO standard and require the team to abandon their current approach

Right Answer: Discuss with PMO how the team's current approach is working well, seek exemption or lighter-weight compliance

Key Exam Traps to Avoid

Trap 1: "No Documentation Ever"

  • Wrong: Agile means we don't write any documentation
  • Right: Agile means we write just enough documentation to support the work and meet compliance needs

Trap 2: "No Planning in Agile"

  • Wrong: Agile projects don't need plans
  • Right: Agile projects have plans that evolve based on learning and change

Trap 3: "Customer Gets Everything They Want"

  • Wrong: Collaboration means saying yes to every request
  • Right: Collaboration means working together to maximize value within constraints

Trap 4: "Contracts Don't Matter"

  • Wrong: Collaboration eliminates the need for contracts
  • Right: Contracts should enable collaboration rather than prevent it

üí° Exam Tips for Agile Manifesto

When You See These Keywords:

  • "Detailed upfront planning" - Usually wrong in Agile contexts
  • "Comprehensive documentation" - Usually wrong unless it's for compliance/safety
  • "Change request denied" - Usually wrong (embrace change!)
  • "Follow the plan" - Usually wrong if conditions have changed

When You See These Keywords:

  • "Collaborate with customer" - Usually right
  • "Working increment" - Usually right
  • "Adapt the approach" - Usually right
  • "Team decides how" - Usually right for implementation details

Remember the Nuance: The Manifesto values items on the left MORE than items on the right. You don't ignore the items on the right‚Äîyou just prioritize the items on the left when there's a conflict.

Final Tip: If an exam question presents a conflict between following a process/plan/contract and delivering value through collaboration/adaptation, choose value delivery and collaboration. That's the Agile mindset PMI expects.
agile-manifesto.examTip: The Agile Manifesto appears in ~60% of exam questions. Remember: value items on LEFT more than RIGHT (not instead of). When stuck, ask yourself: 'Does this answer prioritize people, working products, collaboration, and adaptation?' PMI expects you to embrace Agile values while still being practical about documentation, planning, and contracts when truly needed.

scrum-framework.title: Scrum Framework: Roles, Events, and Artifacts
scrum-framework.content:
Scrum: The Most Popular Agile Framework

Scrum is the most widely used Agile framework and is heavily tested on the PMP exam. Developed by Jeff Sutherland and Ken Schwaber in the early 1990s, Scrum provides a lightweight framework for managing complex work.

Why Scrum Matters for the Exam: PMI recognizes Scrum as a valid approach for many projects. You'll see questions about Scrum roles, events, and artifacts‚Äîand you need to understand how Scrum differs from traditional project management.

Key Concept: Scrum is intentionally incomplete. It defines the minimum framework necessary but allows teams to adapt and fill in the details based on their context.

The Three Pillars of Scrum (Empirical Process Control)

Scrum is built on three pillars that enable empirical process control:

  • Transparency: Significant aspects of the process must be visible to those responsible for the outcome (e.g., visible Kanban boards, daily standups, open information radiators)
  • Inspection: Regularly examine Scrum artifacts and progress toward goals to detect undesirable variances (e.g., Sprint Reviews, Daily Scrums)
  • Adaptation: Adjust the process or product when inspection reveals issues (e.g., changes made during Sprint Planning or Retrospectives)

Exam Application: When questions ask about transparency, information sharing, or adaptation, these pillars provide the rationale.

The Five Scrum Values

Scrum teams embody these values:

  • Commitment: Team commits to achieving goals and supporting each other
  • Courage: Team has courage to do the right thing and work on tough problems
  • Focus: Team focuses on the work of the Sprint and team goals
  • Openness: Team and stakeholders are open about work and challenges
  • Respect: Team members respect each other as capable, independent people

The 3 Scrum Roles

Scrum defines exactly three roles. Important: There is no "Project Manager" role in pure Scrum. These responsibilities are distributed across the three roles.

Role 1: Product Owner (PO)

Primary Responsibility: Maximize the value of the product and the work of the Development Team.

Key Accountabilities:

  • Manage the Product Backlog: Create, communicate, order, and maintain the Product Backlog items
  • Prioritize work: Order backlog items based on business value, risk, dependencies, and learning opportunities
  • Define acceptance criteria: Clarify what "done" means for each backlog item
  • Accept or reject work: Determine whether Sprint work meets the Definition of Done
  • Engage stakeholders: Understand customer needs and communicate them to the team
  • Ensure backlog is transparent: Make sure everyone understands priorities and upcoming work

Important for Exam:

  • The Product Owner is one person, not a committee (though they may represent stakeholders)
  • PO must be empowered to make decisions about priority and scope
  • PO should be available to answer team questions (ideally co-located or readily accessible)
  • PO focuses on the "what" and "why," team focuses on the "how"

Exam Scenario: If a question asks who decides feature priority or what to build next, the answer is the Product Owner.

Role 2: Scrum Master (SM)

Primary Responsibility: Promote and support Scrum by helping everyone understand Scrum theory, practices, rules, and values. The Scrum Master is a servant leader.

Key Accountabilities:

  • Coach the team: Help the team become self-organizing and cross-functional
  • Remove impediments: Clear obstacles that prevent the team from achieving their goals (especially organizational/administrative blockers)
  • Facilitate events: Ensure Scrum events happen and are productive (but don't necessarily run them all)
  • Protect the team: Shield the team from external interruptions and distractions during the Sprint
  • Promote empiricism: Help the team inspect and adapt
  • Serve the Product Owner: Help with backlog management techniques and stakeholder collaboration
  • Serve the organization: Lead Scrum adoption, coach on Agile practices, help plan Scrum implementations

Important for Exam:

  • Scrum Master is not a manager‚Äîthey have no authority over the team
  • SM focuses on process and practices, not product or technical decisions
  • SM removes organizational/administrative impediments; team solves technical issues
  • SM facilitates but doesn't dictate

Common Exam Question: "Team velocity is declining. What should the Scrum Master do?"

  • Right: Facilitate a retrospective to help the team identify and address root causes
  • Wrong: Tell the team to work harder or assign specific tasks

Role 3: Development Team (DT)

Primary Responsibility: Deliver a potentially releasable increment of "Done" product at the end of each Sprint.

Key Characteristics:

  • Self-organizing: Team decides how to turn Product Backlog into Increments
  • Cross-functional: Team has all skills needed to create product increment (no dependency on external specialists)
  • No sub-teams: No titles or sub-roles within the team (everyone is a "Developer")
  • Accountability is collective: The whole team is accountable for delivery, not individuals
  • Size: 3-9 members: Smaller than 3 lacks skill diversity; larger than 9 requires too much coordination

Key Accountabilities:

  • Estimate work: Only the Development Team can estimate effort
  • Commit to Sprint Goal: During Sprint Planning, team commits to work they can complete
  • Create the Increment: Build, test, and deliver working product
  • Own quality: Ensure work meets Definition of Done
  • Collaborate: Work together to achieve Sprint goals

Important for Exam:

  • Team is self-managing for technical decisions
  • Only the team can estimate; Product Owner and Scrum Master don't estimate on team's behalf
  • Team pulls work; work is not assigned to individuals by a manager
  • Team owns the Sprint Backlog and can re-plan within the Sprint as needed

The 5 Scrum Events (Ceremonies)

Scrum uses time-boxed events to create regularity and minimize unnecessary meetings. Each event is an opportunity to inspect and adapt.

Event 1: Sprint Planning

Purpose: Define what will be delivered in the Sprint and how the work will be achieved.

Time-box: Maximum 8 hours for a one-month Sprint (proportionally less for shorter Sprints‚Äîtypically 2-4 hours for a 2-week Sprint)

Attendees: Entire Scrum Team (Product Owner, Scrum Master, Development Team)

Two Key Questions Answered:

  1. What can be delivered in this Sprint? (Product Owner proposes, team assesses capacity)
  2. How will the work get done? (Development Team plans tasks and approach)

Outputs:

  • Sprint Goal: Objective that provides coherence and focus
  • Sprint Backlog: Product Backlog items selected for the Sprint plus a plan for delivering them

Exam Tips:

  • Product Owner proposes priorities, but team has final say on what they can commit to
  • If Product Owner isn't available during Sprint Planning, this is a red flag (SM should address)
  • Sprint Goal provides flexibility‚Äîteam can negotiate scope within the Sprint as long as Sprint Goal is met

Event 2: Daily Scrum (Daily Standup)

Purpose: Synchronize activities and create a plan for the next 24 hours. Inspect progress toward Sprint Goal and adapt Sprint Backlog as necessary.

Time-box: 15 minutes, every day, at the same time and place

Attendees: Development Team (required). Scrum Master ensures it happens but doesn't have to attend unless they're doing development work. Product Owner and stakeholders may attend but don't participate.

Common Structure (Three Questions):

  1. What did I do yesterday that helped the team meet the Sprint Goal?
  2. What will I do today to help the team meet the Sprint Goal?
  3. Do I see any impediment that prevents me or the team from meeting the Sprint Goal?

Important Notes:

  • This is not a status report to the Scrum Master or manager‚Äîit's team communication
  • Team can use any format they prefer (three questions are common but not mandatory)
  • Focus is on the Sprint Goal, not individual tasks
  • Impediments are identified but not resolved during the Daily Scrum (handled afterward)

Exam Scenarios:

  • Q: "Daily Scrum takes 45 minutes. What should you do?"
  • A: Coach the team to keep it to 15 minutes; detailed discussions should happen afterward
  • Q: "Product Owner wants to attend Daily Scrum to hear status updates. What do you do?"
  • A: PO can observe but shouldn't disrupt the team's synchronization; if they need status, schedule separate time

Event 3: Sprint Review

Purpose: Inspect the Increment and adapt the Product Backlog if needed. Demonstrate completed work to stakeholders and gather feedback.

Time-box: Maximum 4 hours for a one-month Sprint (proportionally less for shorter Sprints‚Äîtypically 1-2 hours for a 2-week Sprint)

Attendees: Scrum Team plus stakeholders invited by Product Owner

Key Activities:

  • Product Owner reviews what was and wasn't completed
  • Development Team demonstrates the Increment and answers questions
  • Product Owner discusses the Product Backlog and likely target dates
  • Stakeholders provide feedback on what was demonstrated
  • Group collaborates on what to do next (input for Sprint Planning)

Important Distinctions:

  • This is not a demo to "get approval"‚Äîit's a collaborative working session
  • Only "Done" work is demonstrated (meets Definition of Done)
  • Feedback from this session may change the Product Backlog
  • Focus is on the product and business value, not the team's performance

Exam Tip: Sprint Review focuses on the "what" (product), while Sprint Retrospective (next event) focuses on the "how" (process).

Event 4: Sprint Retrospective

Purpose: Inspect how the last Sprint went regarding people, relationships, process, and tools. Identify improvements for the next Sprint.

Time-box: Maximum 3 hours for a one-month Sprint (proportionally less for shorter Sprints‚Äîtypically 45-90 minutes for a 2-week Sprint)

Attendees: Scrum Team (Product Owner, Scrum Master, Development Team). This is usually a private team session.

Key Activities:

  • Inspect how the last Sprint went (what went well, what could improve)
  • Identify improvements to be implemented in the next Sprint
  • Plan how improvements will be implemented

Common Formats:

  • Start/Stop/Continue (What should we start doing, stop doing, continue doing?)
  • Glad/Sad/Mad (What made us glad, sad, or mad this Sprint?)
  • Sailboat (Wind = helps us, Anchors = slows us down, Rocks = risks ahead)

Critical for Exam:

  • Retrospectives happen every Sprint (continuous improvement)
  • Team must identify at least one improvement to implement in the next Sprint
  • Scrum Master facilitates but doesn't dictate the improvements
  • Focus is on process and collaboration, not the product

Exam Scenarios:

  • Q: "Team wants to skip retrospective because they're behind schedule. What do you do?"
  • A: Never skip retrospectives; continuous improvement is essential for long-term velocity

Event 5: Backlog Refinement (Backlog Grooming)

Purpose: Add detail, estimates, and order to Product Backlog items. Prepare upcoming work for Sprint Planning.

Time-box: Not formally time-boxed, but typically consumes no more than 10% of the Development Team's capacity

Attendees: Product Owner and Development Team (Scrum Master may attend)

Key Activities:

  • Break down large items (epics) into smaller user stories
  • Estimate effort for backlog items (using story points, t-shirt sizes, etc.)
  • Clarify acceptance criteria and details
  • Re-order backlog based on value, risk, dependencies

Important Notes:

  • This is not a formal Scrum event (unlike the other four), but it's a common practice
  • It's an ongoing activity throughout the Sprint, not a single meeting
  • Product Owner owns the backlog, but team provides input and estimates

Exam Tip: If a question mentions the team is unprepared for Sprint Planning because stories are too large or unclear, the answer is usually to invest more time in backlog refinement.

The 3 Scrum Artifacts

Scrum artifacts represent work or value and are designed to maximize transparency of key information.

Artifact 1: Product Backlog

Definition: An ordered list of everything that is known to be needed in the product. It's the single source of requirements for any changes to be made to the product.

Characteristics:

  • Owned by Product Owner: PO is responsible for its content, availability, and ordering
  • Dynamic: Constantly evolving as product and business conditions change
  • Ordered by value: Highest value items at the top (not necessarily highest priority by time)
  • Contains all requirements: Features, functions, requirements, enhancements, fixes
  • Never complete: As long as the product exists, the backlog exists

Common Formats for Items:

  • User Stories: "As a [role], I want [feature] so that [benefit]"
  • Epics: Large bodies of work that can be broken down into stories
  • Technical debt items: Refactoring, architecture improvements
  • Bugs/defects: Issues discovered in existing functionality

Exam Tips:

  • Only Product Owner can change the Product Backlog (though anyone can influence them)
  • Items at the top should be more detailed ("ready" for Sprint Planning)
  • Items at the bottom can be less detailed (may not be worked on for months)

Artifact 2: Sprint Backlog

Definition: The set of Product Backlog items selected for the Sprint, plus a plan for delivering the product Increment and realizing the Sprint Goal.

Characteristics:

  • Owned by Development Team: Team creates and manages it
  • Visible and transparent: Often shown on a task board (To Do, In Progress, Done)
  • Updated daily: As team learns more, they adjust the plan
  • Scope can be clarified/renegotiated: Team can work with Product Owner to adjust during Sprint if Sprint Goal is still achievable

Components:

  • Selected Product Backlog items (user stories)
  • Tasks needed to complete those items
  • Sprint Goal (the objective)

Important for Exam:

  • Only the Development Team can change the Sprint Backlog
  • Team pulls work; no one assigns tasks to individuals
  • Sprint Backlog is a forecast, not a guarantee

Artifact 3: Increment

Definition: The sum of all Product Backlog items completed during a Sprint combined with all previous Sprints' Increments. The Increment must be in usable condition and meet the Definition of Done.

Characteristics:

  • Potentially releasable: It could go to production, even if Product Owner chooses not to release it
  • "Done" means done: Meets the team's Definition of Done (tested, integrated, documented as needed)
  • Cumulative: Each Sprint's Increment builds on previous Increments
  • Inspected at Sprint Review: Stakeholders see working product, not plans or promises

Definition of Done (DoD): A shared understanding of what it means for work to be complete. May include:

  • Code is written and peer-reviewed
  • Unit tests pass
  • Integration tests pass
  • Documentation is updated
  • Acceptance criteria met
  • Deployed to staging environment

Exam Importance: Definition of Done is critical for transparency. Without it, teams may claim work is done when it's not releasable.

Exam Scenario: If question asks why quality is low or rework is high, check if team has a clear Definition of Done.

Sprint Mechanics: How It All Flows Together

Sprint Time-Box

  • Duration: 1-4 weeks (2 weeks is most common)
  • Consistent length: Once chosen, Sprint length stays the same for predictability
  • No extensions: Sprint ends on time, even if work isn't complete

Sprint Goal

The Sprint Goal is an objective set during Sprint Planning that gives the team flexibility:

  • Provides coherence so team works toward common objective
  • Allows negotiation of scope within the Sprint (as long as Goal is still met)
  • Should be achievable within the Sprint

Example Sprint Goals:

  • "Enable users to search for products by category"
  • "Improve system performance for 10,000 concurrent users"
  • "Complete user registration and login flows"

Typical Sprint Flow

  1. Sprint Planning: Define Sprint Goal and Sprint Backlog (Day 1)
  2. Daily Scrums: Synchronize daily (Days 1-14)
  3. Backlog Refinement: Prepare future work (ongoing)
  4. Development Work: Build the Increment (Days 1-14)
  5. Sprint Review: Demonstrate Increment to stakeholders (Day 14)
  6. Sprint Retrospective: Inspect and adapt process (Day 14)
  7. Next Sprint Planning: Immediately begins (Day 15)

Important: There is no gap between Sprints. When one ends, the next begins immediately.

Scrum Master vs. Project Manager: Key Differences

This is a common source of exam questions. Understanding the difference is critical:

AspectTraditional PMScrum Master
AuthorityHas authority over team and decisionsNo authority; serves the team
FocusScope, schedule, budget, qualityTeam effectiveness and process
PlanningCreates detailed upfront planFacilitates team planning
Task AssignmentAssigns work to team membersTeam self-organizes and pulls work
ImpedimentsSolves problemsRemoves blockers, coaches team to solve
DecisionsMakes key project decisionsFacilitates team decision-making
ScopeControls scope changesProduct Owner manages scope

Exam Tip: When a question describes a Scrum context and asks what the "project manager" should do, mentally replace "project manager" with "Scrum Master" and choose the servant leadership answer.

Common Exam Scenarios for Scrum

Scenario 1: Who Decides Priority?

Q: "A stakeholder wants a specific feature added to the current Sprint. What should you do?"

A: Direct the stakeholder to the Product Owner. Only the PO can change backlog priority. If it's truly urgent, PO might work with team to swap Sprint Backlog items, but team has final say on what's feasible.

Scenario 2: Sprint Goal at Risk

Q: "Midway through Sprint, it's clear the team won't finish all Sprint Backlog items. What should you do?"

A: Team should collaborate with Product Owner to re-negotiate scope while keeping Sprint Goal achievable. Focus on delivering highest-value items that meet the Sprint Goal. Sprint length doesn't change.

Scenario 3: External Interruptions

Q: "Senior manager keeps pulling team members into other meetings during the Sprint. What should the Scrum Master do?"

A: Scrum Master should protect the team by discussing with the manager how these interruptions affect Sprint commitment and team performance. Educate on Scrum principles and request that urgent items go through Product Owner for proper prioritization.

Scenario 4: Low Velocity

Q: "Team velocity has been declining for three Sprints. What should you do?"

A: Facilitate a retrospective focused on identifying root causes. Could be technical debt, unclear requirements, external dependencies, team morale, or other factors. Let the team identify and implement improvements.

üí° Exam Tips for Scrum Framework

Role Questions - Quick Guide:

  • Product Owner: Anything about priority, value, backlog, what to build
  • Scrum Master: Anything about process, impediments, coaching, facilitation
  • Development Team: Anything about how to build, estimates, technical decisions

Event Questions - Quick Guide:

  • Sprint Planning: Commitment and approach questions
  • Daily Scrum: Synchronization and coordination questions
  • Sprint Review: Product demonstration and stakeholder feedback questions
  • Sprint Retrospective: Process improvement and team dynamics questions

Remember:

  • Scrum Master is a servant leader, not a manager
  • Team is self-organizing for the "how"
  • Product Owner owns the "what" and "why"
  • Sprints are time-boxed and do not extend
  • Only "Done" work is demonstrated
  • Continuous improvement through retrospectives is mandatory

Common Wrong Answers:

  • "Skip the retrospective" - Never!
  • "Extend the Sprint" - Never!
  • "Scrum Master assigns tasks" - No, team self-organizes
  • "Demonstrate incomplete work" - No, only Done work
scrum-framework.examTip: Scrum questions test your understanding of roles, events, and artifacts. Remember: Product Owner owns 'what', Scrum Master facilitates 'how team works', Development Team owns 'how to build'. Scrum Master is a servant leader with no authority. Sprints are time-boxed and never extended. Retrospectives are mandatory every Sprint. Know the 3-9 team size rule and that only Done work is demonstrated.

kanban-lean.title: Kanban, XP, and Lean Principles
kanban-lean.content:
Beyond Scrum: Other Agile Approaches

While Scrum is the most popular Agile framework, the PMP exam also tests your knowledge of Kanban and Lean principles. Understanding these approaches‚Äîand when to use them‚Äîis essential for selecting the right methodology for your project context.

Kanban: Visualize Flow and Limit Work in Progress

Kanban originated in Japanese manufacturing (Toyota Production System) and was adapted for knowledge work by David Anderson in the 2000s. Unlike Scrum, Kanban is not prescriptive‚Äîit's a method you overlay on your existing process.

The 6 Core Practices of Kanban

Practice 1: Visualize the Workflow

Purpose: Make work visible so everyone can see what's happening, what's blocked, and where bottlenecks exist.

Implementation: Use a Kanban board with columns representing workflow stages:

  • Basic board: To Do | In Progress | Done
  • Development board: Backlog | Analysis | Development | Testing | Done
  • Marketing board: Ideas | Planned | In Creation | Review | Published

Key Elements:

  • Cards/tickets: Each work item is represented visually
  • Columns: Represent stages in your workflow
  • Swim lanes (optional): Horizontal rows to categorize work (e.g., by priority, work type, or team)
  • WIP limits: Numbers indicating maximum items allowed in each column

Exam Tip: Visualization is the foundation of Kanban. If a question asks how to increase transparency or help stakeholders understand work status, a Kanban board is often the answer.

Practice 2: Limit Work in Progress (WIP)

Purpose: Reduce multitasking and context switching by limiting how much work is in progress at any time. This improves flow and reduces cycle time.

Why WIP Limits Work:
